page.title: 01Heritage, Local History
page.content: Local tradition asserts that the name Blackford derives from the drowning of Queen Helen at a ford near the Milton of Panholes in the 9th century. While traces of human settlement and activity are apparent from early times, the village of Blackford itself dates from the second half of the 17th century. Little physical evidence of the early village survives but some house sites date back to the burning of Blackford by the Jacobyte army in 1716. In the original parish church yard, one of Scotlands only two Lych Gates can be seen. The local Blackford church has a link in an important event in Scottish history. The minister of Blackford the Reverend John Clark, put forward the famous motion to the Auchterarder Presbytery which led to the Disruption of 1843
